<@!688889240125308981> hmm. what sort of entity are you asking about exactly? Which peers on the network publish blocks?

author: afdudley
content: Thinking about the miner as an entity that exists within devp2p may cause you problems depending on what sort of analysis you're trying to do.

author: sandra_johnson
content: What I am aiming to do <@!332923501079953409> is to have a prior probability distribution across the type of nodes running on the Ethereum network. In this instance I am trying to estimate the proportion of nodes that are miners, versus those that are full nodes. I am not distinguishing between full and archive nodes, and light nodes are out of scope for the model we are developing.

author: afdudley
content: That doesn't entirely make sense to me. How are you defining a miner?

author: afdudley
content: do you literally mean a geth node that has turned on mining? They don't advertise that, right? so how would you know? Sorry if I'm being an idiot here, but I don't see the mapping between these things...

author: afdudley
content: Even though we can define a miner in private as, "when I set the miner flag on my client" that's not really the definition of an entity or more specifically enode that publishes blocks or contributes to the creation of blocks prior to publication.

author: sandra_johnson
content: Yes, that is the problem, I cannot know at any one time who could potentially be mining, and that is not really something I need to know for the prior distribution. I would like to know, historically, the proportion of nodes actively mining. I thought I could have a  look historically for account public keys that have received mining rewards. Does that make sense, or can you suggest another approach? My aim is purely to get an idea (somehow) of the percentage of nodes actually mining. I realise that this changes daily and only having the miner flag switched on does not mean active participation as a miner, but I am trying to find some way of estimating the proportions. Would really appreciate any thoughts & suggestions

author: afdudley
content: I spent an embarrassing amount of money answering a similar question. Strictly speaking I don't think there is a cogent answer to your question. Miners run customer software. You can set up probes all over the IP space and try to detect which IP blocks emit Ethereum blocks, I started on this work, but there is no mapping between devp2p enodes and miners.

author: sandra_johnson
content: Thanks for your insights! Much appreciated. Never anticipated how difficult it would be estimating this.

author: afdudley
content: I will say this, transactions come from one part of the internet, blocks come from a different part of the internet. Most of the nodes on something like this: https://www.ethernodes.org/countries are sending transactions (if anything at all) into the network, not blocks.

author: sandra_johnson
content: Interesting, thanks for drawing my attention to this. I didn't think about the transactions and blocks coming from different parts of the internet, but that is obvious had I thought about it!

author: afdudley
content: For example, Iran is not on that list, but there is an Iranian farm, and it's unlikely that their blocks would register as coming from Iran.

author: sandra_johnson
content: Yes tracing origins is a whole different and big challenge!
